Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of Americans out of work by stating that there are 25 million, while the actual number is closer to 23.8 million.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or sources to back up the statement.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that all Americans who are working part-time for economic reasons should be considered "out of work," which is a problematic assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation for the discrepancy between the claim and the official unemployment statistics, which is the inclusion of individuals who are marginally attached to the labor force and those working part-time but prefer full-time jobs.
Understate: The claim understates the number of unemployed Americans by only considering the official unemployment rate and not including those who have stopped looking for work or are working part-time.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there were about 13.1 million unemployed Americans in December 2011, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
